data.title: Gordon Ramsay's wife Tana shares epic snaps to mark 27th anniversary
data.meta_description: Gordon Ramsay's wife Tana Ramsay celebrated their 27th wedding anniversary by sharing some incredible throwback photos.
data.text:
Gordon and Tana Ramsay celebrated their 27th wedding anniversary with some epic throwback snaps on Thursday.

The pair tied the knot on December 21, 1996 in Chelsea, London and their daughter Holly, 23, made sure to take a look at where it all began to mark the occasion.

Holly posted one photo of Gordon, now 57, and Tana, now 49, on their wedding day, along with another showing the famous chef rocking some curtains and a striped suit, while Tana opted for a colourful leather jacket.

A slightly more recent one showed Tana – who re-posted the images to her own Instagram account – in a silk dress, while the pair both went for all-black ensembles in a further shot.

The trip down memory lane came after Gordon and Tana announced they’d welcomed their sixth baby together last month.

The Hell’s Kitchen star shared some pictures from the hospital as they held their new bundle of joy.

He wrote: ‘What an amazing birthday present please welcome Jesse James Ramsay, 7lbs 10oz whopper!!

‘One more bundle of love to the Ramsay brigade!! 3 boys, 3 girls…. Done,’ Gordon insisted.

Tana also shared the adorable family snaps with the latest addition.

She admitted: ‘It’s been a nerve wracking 9 months but we’ve made it and we have been blessed with this little bundle. Ramsay family definitely complete.

‘Jesse James Ramsay we love you so much.’

Gordon and Tana already have Megan, 25, twins Holly and Jack, 23, Tilly, 22, and youngest son Oscar, four.

The baby announcement comes after Gordon spoke about having more kids on multiple occasions.

He admitted he was worried about having another child at his age earlier this year.

Gordon made the comments on the Dish podcast with Nick Grimshaw and Angela Hartnett, discussing the complication of the sheer number of children, joking they would need ‘two buses’ to go out to dinner or get to school.

‘I’m going to be the oldest f****r at school,’ he complained.

‘”Who’s your grandad?” And what about sports day, and the egg and spoon race? What am I going to do?’

Despite all of this, he confessed he would ‘love another one’ but said at the time that ‘five is enough for now.’
